welcome.text:
Please wait for the experimenter.

If you have not done so already, please silence your cell phone and put away all personal belongs.

Please DO NOT press 'Next' until the experimenter tells you to begin.

start.title: Instructions
start.text:
In today's experiment you will be doing a series of tasks on the computer using the keyboard and mouse to respond.


Click 'Next' for instructions about the first task.

encodingInstuctions.title: Instructions
encodingInstuctions.text:
For the first task, you will be learning pairs of words for a later test.


On some trials of this task, you will see a single word on the screen with a textbox below. For example, you might see:

snow

On trials like this, your task is to guess a related word that you think might be paired with the word on the screen. You will have 7 seconds to type your guess into the textbox. Please use this time wisely and try to make a guess for each word.


After 7 seconds, you will be shown feedback about your guess. That is, you will see the correct pair of words together on the screen for 5 seconds. These are the words that you should study and remember for a later test. For example, if you saw:

snow -- sled

You should try to memorize that pair of words and remember that they belong together.


On some trials you will not need to make a guess first. That is, sometimes, you will simply be shown a pair of words together on the screen and you will have 5 seconds to study the pair of words and remember that they belong together.


Regardless of whether you make a guess first or not, you will have 5 seconds to study and memorize each pair of words.

For all trials of this task, the experiment will automatically advance after the allotted time. On trials in which you make a guess, you DO NOT need to press 'Enter' to submit your guess. Instead, you will be shown feedback about your guess after 7 seconds have passed.


If you have any questions, please raise your hand, and wait for the experimenter to come answer them.


When you are ready to begin, click 'Next'.

distractorInstructions.title: Math Problem Instructions
distractorInstructions.text:
In the next task, you will be shown a series of math problems one at a time. We would like you to solve each as quickly as you can and type the correct answer into the textbox.


When you are ready to begin, click 'Next'.

test.title: Memory Test
test.text:
Now, we are going to test your memory for the pairs of words that you studied during the first part of the experiment.


On each trial of this test, you will be shown a word and a textbox together on the screen. Each word will be from one of the pairs of words that you studied earlier. For each word, please try to remember the other word that it was paired with and type that word into the textbox provided.


For example, during the instructions at the beginning of the experiment, “snow -- sled” was used as an example of a pair of words that you might need to study and remember. If on the test you were shown:

snow

Your task would be to remember that “snow” and “sled” were paired together and then type “sled” into the textbox.


Some of the words you will be shown on this test will be words that you made guesses about earlier in the experiment. We DO NOT want you to try to remember what you guessed earlier in the experiment. That is, we only want you to remember what you were told was the correct pair after you made your guess. Please avoid guessing. That is, you should only type a word into the textbox if you remember studying those two words together as a pair.


If you cannot remember the correct word to complete the pair, simply leave the textbox empty. You will have 7 seconds to remember the correct word and type it into the textbox. Please use your time wisely and keep this time limit in mind.


If you have any questions, please raise your hand, and wait for the experimenter to come answer them.


When you are ready to begin, click 'Next'.

demographics.title: Demographics Instructions
demographics.text:
The experiment is almost over.

Now, we would like to collect some demographic information about you. You do not have to answer any questions you are not comfortable with. The information you provide will not be used to identify you in any way.

If you do not wish to answer one of the questions, simply select 'No' or type a 0 in the corresponding text-box.

Click 'Next' when you are ready to continue.

end.title: Thank you for participating!
end.text:
You have completed the experiment. Please wait quietly while all other participants finish the experiment. You will be dismissed by the experimenter when everyone has finished.

Because this is an ongoing study and many other students will participate, we ask that you not discuss specific details about the study with other students.

Click 'Continue' to view the debriefing page.

debrief.title: Debriefing: #950 Memory Experiment
debrief.text:
What is the general aim of this research?

The experiment you participated in today is part of a larger study investigating strategies that enhance memory. One strategy examined in this research is known as retrieval practice, which is the finding that practicing retrieval of knowledge can promote learning often to a greater extent than the opportunity for additional study. We are interested in whether your memory will be better for materials over which you were tested versus material for which you studied.

Is this correlational or experimental research?

The study you participated in represents experimental research. The independent variable we manipulated was the study technique you engaged in (e.g., repeated studying vs. repeated retrieval), and the dependent variable we are interested in is your performance on a final test. We predict that practicing repeated retrieval will produce better retention than repeated studying.

What topic in introductory psychology does this research illustrate?

The current research falls within the general area of human learning and memory. For an overview of research on human memory, see Chapter 8 in Nairne’s Psychology: The Adaptive Mind (4th Edition), Chapter 9 in Meyers’ Psychology (8th Edition), or Chapter 9 in Gray’s Psychology (5th Edition). Another excellent book covering current research on human memory is The Seven Sins of Memory, by Dan Schacter.

Where can I learn more about this type of research?

If you are interested in learning more about retrieval practice, here are two relevant references:

Karpicke, J. D., & Roediger, H. L. (2007). Repeated retrieval during learning is the key to long-term retention. Journal of Memory and Language, 57, 151-162.

Karpicke, J. D., & Roediger, H. L. (2008). The critical importance of retrieval for learning. Science, 319, 966-968.

Which faculty member is supervising this research and how can I contact her/him?

Dr. Jeffrey Karpicke, a professor in cognitive psychology, is supervising this research. You may reach him at 494-0273, via email at karpicke@purdue.edu, or in room PRCE 389.

How long has the investigator been studying this specific topic and how does this experiment fit into the investigator's program of research?

Dr. Karpicke began investigating human learning and memory over 15 years ago. The current experiments are designed to examine other ways that basic research on learning and memory can be applied to enhance educational practice.

A lot of research in psychology depends on the participation of individuals like you. We are very grateful for your help. Thank you very much for participating.
